title: facebook groups offering tigers cheetahs vipers sale uk
story: A Sun Online investigation found people offering rare and dangerous animals for sale on the social networks - seemingly without any proper checks.The shocking news was revealed with a search on the online giant, that brought up dozens of groups.We joined a number of the groups and within hours of being a member we had been offered cheetah, tiger, lion and leopard cubs.One seller, based in Turkey, advertised tiger cubs for £, each, lion cubs for £, each and leopard cubs for £, each.They claimed they could ship to the UK and they would arrive in two days max.He said: They are well trained and well tamed too. They can stay indoors.The seller added: I will need a day to get them ready and then documents will be supplied...after that I will carry them to American Airlines and register them for a flight.When they arrive in the UK, you will be notied and after that they will be delivered to your address.You only need to make an advance payment for the process and once you receive the cubs and confirm they are in good health, you pay our balance.They come with registration papers and a DVD...you can learn more from the disc. When they get bigger they will be perfect and you will enjoy them more.In a breach of Facebook guidelines, one trader advertised tiger cubs for £,, Transvaal lion cubs for £,, African lion cubs for £, and cheetah cubs for £,.Another seller claimed he could deliver a leopard cub from Germany to the buyer’s home address in Britain for £, plus an extra £ for shipping costs.He said: “Leopard cubs are fast selling pets and loved by many people around the world.”Under UK law people who keep animals that are wild, dangerous or exotic must apply to their local council for a licence.They are granted onlythey can provide necessary safety measures at their home and after a fee is paid.None of those selling exotic animals on Facebook mentioned the need to obtain a licence from the local authority.Animal welfare officials have called on social media companies to do more to crack down on the trade.Lis Key, of International Animal Rescue, told the Sun Online: “The internet does make it easier for the traders to hide – and easier for them to reach a vast market.Traders are increasingly turning to social media sites like Facebook to sell exotic animals.In terms of what the dangers are of selling exotic animals on the internet: clearly neither the buyers or sellers can have the animals’ best interests at heart. The former are seeking trophies, the latter are out to make money.“The animals are often kept hidden away in cramped conditions and go without food or water for long periods of time. Inevitably, many die before they are even sold. Perhaps they are the lucky ones.”Richard Thomas, from TRAFFIC, the wildle trade monitoring group, told the Sun Online: “It’s so dficult to police because most of the Facebook groups are private closed.“It’s a new avenue which the criminal underworld will try to exploit.Martin Simms, Director of Investigations at the League Against Cruel Sports, has dealt with cases including the attempted sale of dead bats online and the suspected sale of sperm whale teeth hacked from the mouth of a dead whale washed up on a British beach.He believes Facebook has a duty to halt any illegal wildle activity.There have also been cases where wild British hedgehogs have been passed off as exotic African Pygmy Hedgehogs by rustlers trying to sell them as pets on Facebook, as well as sites such as Gumtree.In a separate case, in April last year champion cage fighter Steve Dossett sparked outrage when he posted pictures of orphaned fox cubs on his social media page and asked for £ per animal.He posted photos of them in a box in his home and wrote “fox cubs for sale,  pounds lovely pets”.In another post under another photograph, he wrote foxes drinking milk out of a bowl, who wants one Horried animal lovers saw the ad and begged him to take the animals to a shelter instead.Eventually, a member of Dossett’s family called Surrey-based Wildle Aid Foundation and volunteers from the charity went to his flat and took seven cubs away.Facebook told the Sun Online it is investigating.

title: amsterdam red light district exxpose
story: This is Amsterdam’s infamous Red Light District, where an estimated , sex workers do their best to entice men - often on weekend stag dos - to splash their cash.Over  million tourists visit the city each year, drawn by the citys liberal stance when it comes to drugs and buying sex.Yet the citys infamous red light district is now under threat.While buying sex is legal in the Netherlands as long as it is between two consenting adults, a campaign group spearheaded by feminists and Christians are trying to overturn this.The Dutch parliament is now set to debate whether to change the law, after the group Exxpose generated a petition with over , signatures.Campaigners cite the rise in sex trafficking victims as reason to criminalise buying sex  - in  alone there was believed to have been a  per cent rise in human trafficking, with the majority forced into prostitution.But sex workers in the red light district - who make up to £ an hour - are up in arms at the idea of their livelihoods being taken away.Theyve slammed feminist campaigners as patronising and asked -  how can you call yourself a feminist and try to take away other womens job Here, one sex worker and one young woman campaigning to close down the red light district go head-to-head...Make no mistake, it’s the sex workers who are in charge in the windows of Amsterdam.They set the rules and they decide whether to let a client in or not. They have a panic button that summons the window manager, andhe needs to, he’ll call the police without hesitation.There are so many police cameras and CCTV cameras in the Red Light District I’d say it’s actually one of the safest places to work, and I’ve been a sex worker for five years.I do it because I like it, not for the money or because it’s my only option.I’m , although I tell clients I’m  , and I have a few boyfriends, nothing serious.My le is pretty normal and I’d say I’m actually pretty privileged - I’ve got a degree and I worked as a nurse.When I was doing that I saw a lot of the patients craved physical affection. Sometimes they told you nicely, sometimes they misbehaved and grabbed you.But the patients weren’t put first at hospital, so I changed my job.Now, as well as the sex work, I’m a district nurse in people’s houses.I like it because it gives you more time to spend one-on-one with your patients and that’s what I like about sex work as well – it’s absolute quality time.I make a lot of people very happy and it’s rewarding in lots of ways. It’s not just the money.I prefer sex work to nursing but the people at Exxpose tell me I don’t know my own mind, and that’s what annoys me.They say the consent of vulnerable people is being bought by men with money and power – that’s a ridiculous generalisation. In reality it’s a business transaction like any other. I’m an independent entrepreneur who pays her taxes – quite a lot of taxes, actually. I get  eurosfor one hour.What the people behind the Exxpose campaign aren’t telling you is that it’s all rooted in their religion.They’re trying to save us when we don’t need saving – except maybe from the saviours themselves!They only see and hear what they want to – they think sex workers must have had a bad childhood or be addicts. They’re changing the facts to suit their argument.If two people of legal age agree to have sex, what’s wrong with that It’s true that there are bad things going on in the Red Light District, human trafficking does exist but its also re in other industries such as the restaurant trade – but I don’t see the Exxpose lot campaigning to make it illegal to buy a Chinese takeaway.It’s true that the Brits have a reputation in the Red Light District because of the amount of beer they drink, which goes hand in hand with some pretty bad behaviour.But let’s not forget our boys from the Dutch countryside, who can be just as boisterous.The Brits come here on stag dos, granted, but the same bad behaviour happens in Barcelona and Madrid – and there’s no Red Light District in those cities.Decriminalising sex work altogether it is the best policyyou ask me.I thought the whole point of feminism was empowering women to do as they please, not restricting their rights and opportunities.These Exxpose campaigners are young and naïve. I hope when they’re my age they’ll look back and think, What on earth was I thinking, telling other people what to do In the Netherlands it’s illegal to put puppies in a pet shop window because we believe it’s cruel – and yet we put our young women behind a window and pretend it’s normal.Tourists can walk around the Red Light District gawping at them without paying any money at all – those ladies are a tourist attraction and a lot of people get to see them in their underwear for free.Our campaign is staffed by volunteers, mostly young people. We see too much harm going on, too much human trafficking and we object to the normalisation of the buying of sex.It isn’t about a woman’s right to sell sex. Women should be free to do what they want with their bodies - I can totally understand why people do it and I think it’s a really brave decision to sell sex.I can totally imagine doing that.Demand for prostitution in countries who follow the Nordic Model, as this law is known, has decreased too.The idea is that making it a criminal offense to buy sex reduces sex trafficking.Estimates of the amount of prostitutes in the Netherlands y, but there are thought to be between , and ,.In , officials suggested that about £million a year was spent on sex transactions in the country. Sex workers there now pay tax on their earnings.In , the number of prostitutes in the UK was estimated as being ,, while one in ten men admit paying for sex.I grew up in a village near Rotterdam with my brother and four sisters.Things were comfortable, my mum was a nurse and my dad had his own aluminium business.They’re both Christians and that’s how I was raised, I still go to church and I’m married.It all plays into the campaign because I knew I was blessed growing up, that others didn’t have what I did. I worked in a rehab centre for a while and I saw that.I knew I wanted to help people, and after I saw a documentary about sex work things clicked.I spoke to my friends and we realised that we might be able to really change thingswe could get the government to talk about the issue.The problem is the men who want to buy sex here typically don’t respect women’s boundaries. They’ve drunk a lot and they behave extremely badly, asking for really cheap prices.They ask for things their wives won’t do: anal sex or role-play where the woman pretends to be a -year-old girl.There’s a lot of violence by customers, they want to have sex without a condom or be so rough the woman bleeds, and the women are under pressure to put up with it or clients won’t pay.Most people selling sex are vulnerable women who need the money or who have been forced into sex work. Because it’s legal to pay for sex, men using their services can ignore the horrible realities behind their actions.Europol research from  shows that Amsterdam is susceptible to human trafficking precisely because we have a big market for cheap sex.So it’s the so-called “ethics” of paying for sex which need to be revisited.There’s a saying in Dutch that everything that anything that can be bought can also be stolen. In you think about that, you can begin to see how prostitution fuels rape.We believe that you cannot buy consent under any circumstances. It’s the men and women who buy sex who would be punished under our proposal and most of them would stopit were made illegal.What do we propose for the women who will be made unemployed by the shrinking of the market  We’d get them into dferent jobs in safe environments which don’t make them vulnerable to sexual abuse.People say that our campaign is funded by the church mafia but that’s not true.Yes I go to church but this is a matter of feminist principle and our approach makes a lot of sense to the large number of young people who support us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: social mobility toff at top no10
story: Not that Old Etonians always make good Prime Ministers.The last one was David Cameron, and lookwhat a national catastrophe he turned out to be.For anyone who cares about social mobility, the depressing news is that  Downing Street is reserved for toffs. Boris will only be our th Prime Minister since the very first, Robert Walpole, who was in office from  to .The fact that more than a third of them went to Eton , suggests that social mobility in this country is in terminal decline.Indeed, when it comes to the children of ordinary homes reaching the highest office in the land, social mobility is stone-cold dead.Fee-paying privilege provides the fast-track to power. Yet it wasn’t always this way.There was a golden age of ­meritocracy in the last century when it was normal for our PMs to be educated by the state.Eton was still a bastion of academic excellence in those happy years. So was Harrow, which has produced seven Prime Ministers, and Westminster, which educated six.But between  and , there was enough healthy social mobility in this country for Harold Wilson, Ted Heath, Jim Callaghan, Margaret Thatcher and John Major — all educated at state schools — to become Prime Minister.Major and Callaghan didn’t even go to university. Callaghan couldn’t afford it, while Major left school at  with three O-levels.All five came from modest ­backgrounds, although Wilson, Heath and Thatcher were clever enough to get into Oxford University.For more than three decades, state-educated politicians competed with those who were the product of expensive private educations — and beat them to the top job.This is not an argument against Boris Johnson becoming Prime ­Minister simply because he went to Eton. Boris seems like the man most likely to prevent a Marxist government. This would destroy our economy — a fate far worse than either staying in or leaving the European Union.SoI was a Tory MP or party member, then I would probably prefer Boris to take on Brussels, Corbyn and the Brexit Party.But yet another old Etonian in  Downing Street proves that social mobility is nowhere near what it was in the last century. Andwe care about a fair and equal society, then that should concern us all.It feels signicant that the first candidate to be eliminated from the Tory leadership race was Esther McVey — the candidate from  the least privileged background, reinforcing the belief that Westminster is a closed shop.But when it comes to getting on in le, and even getting to Downing Street, it should not matter a damn where you were born.Your ability — and your willingness to graft — should matter far more than Mummy and Daddy’s bank ­balance.Le can never be totally fair. But two Old Etonian PMs in less than ten years is grotesque.  If there is to be a bright, shining future for this country after we leave the EU, there MUST be more social mobility.Once he has sorted out Brexit  and buried Corbyn, perhaps our Old ­Etonian PM will do something about it. Because inequality is still entrenched at birth.And that stinks.WHAT is mankind’s greatest invention  The Internet  The printing press  The steam engine  Penicillin If, like me, you are allergic to penicillin, then the gold shorts that Kylie Minogue wore in her Spinning Around promo probably have the edge on all of them. Kylie’s gold gear might make a comeback when she plays Glastonbury next Sunday.And  years after their debut, nobody has ever developed an allergy to them.As the wolf evolved into the dog, it sussed that making its eyes bigger made the humans go all soft and gooey inside.Dr Juliane Kaminski, of the University of Ports- mouth, says: “The evidence is compelling that dogs developed a muscle to raise the inner eyebrow after they were domesticated from wolves. It seems to elicit a strong desire in humans to look after them.”Those puppy-dog eyes are designed to make your heart melt.Certainly when Stan, our Cavalier King Charles spaniel, looks at me with his enormous, big round peepers, I understand the three little words he is trying to say.Give. Stan. Cheese.IT is weird the way even the greatest TV series can go off the boil.On the surface, the second series of Killing Eve has everything that made the first such a blast.Jodie Comer is still brilliant as psychopathic assassin Villanelle, doing a iety of convincing accents and changing her clothes more often than Diana Ross in concert.Sandra Oh is again wonderful as the sexually confused, domestically challenged spook.But I have watched the entire second series now and it just doesn’t catch fire the way the first did.And that is because the first series of Killing Eve had three female stars in Jodie Comer, Sandra Oh and – behind the scenes – Fleabag creator Phoebe Waller-Bridge, who wrote the script.Now Waller-Bridge has gone off to save the screenplay of the next James Bond movie.And Killing Eve badly misses her magic dust.JEW-HATING has become the racism  that is permissible.The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, told the Cambridge Union debating society that his Jewish friends: “Are not like the other Jews – that’s why they are my friends.”He got a laugh.If he had said “black” or “Muslim”, he would have been nicked.THERE are some scary TV shows out there.Doing Question Time is daunting because you can be certain that at least half of the audience will hate your guts.Have I Got News For You  is forbidding because the ageing team captains and presenters have been doing it since the dawn of time and are used to the show’s format .But nothing comes close to the terror factor of Mastermind.To sit in that black leather chair as the lights go down is to know true stage fright. So Hamish Cameron must have been a very brave man indeed.Hamish held the record for the most appearances on Mastermind –  – and after filming the final last November, he learned he had terminal cancer.Shortly before the final was broadcast last week, Hamish died at the age of .The BBC had considered postponing the broadcast as a mark of respect but Hamish had instructed his family that he wanted the show to go on.As someone who vowed “never again” after sitting in that hot seat just the once, I can only salute Hamish’s courage.The Mastermind catchphrase “I’ve started so I’ll finish” could have been invented for this fearless man.IF Heathrow gets a third runway, then the impact on the environment will be huge, with hundreds of extra flights landing and taking  off every day.And that’s just for Emma Thompson!Their honeymoon must have been filthy.ANDREA LEADSOM says she was told by senior Tory women that they could not back her because the party couldn’t have “another woman” Prime Minister so soon after Theresa May.But the Tories’ past willingness to be led by a woman is surely something to celebrate.  The Conservatives will almost certainly be on their third female Prime Minister before the -year-old male-dominated Labour Party has its first.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: love island 2019 insecurities
story: It is a phenomenon and has the nation gripped. So why feel guilty about watching it The appeal of this show is fairly obvious — it’s the intimate access you get.Viewers feel like they’re on holiday on on the island too, as invisible guests.The ultimate fly-on-the-wall experience.We hear the most private of conversations, witness the most explosive fallouts. We even get in the shower with them.It’s so intimate that it feels the same as when you read someone ’s diary.Of course, we are watching insanely beautul people parading around in tiny scraps of swimwear. But no matter how gorgeous the contestants, each one is revealed to be as fragile as the next.I think that is where our real fascination lies.Surely they should all be full of confidence, looking the way they do  And yet they seem to be just as insecure as the rest of us.I like the fact that the show is a portal into a generation to which I no longer belong.I’ve learned so much about how young men and women behave and, until Maura uttered the words, I didn’t even know it was possible to have “fanny flutters”.Another thing I like is the escapism. Surely it’s no coincidence that Love Island is at peak popularity during a time when the news is totally dominated with gloom, doom — and Brexit.Personally, I’m also intrigued by the fake hair and nails — and the very y process of getting ready for a night out. I’m luckyI put a comb through my hair.The amount of make-up they manage to get on to their faces is astonishing — although the irony is that the one girl all the guys seem to like, Lucie, is a surfer chick who doesn’t wear make-up.There is also a real cruelty to the show, though. There is always someone better, someone more chosen. The voting process is brutal and leaves all of the contestants anxious about whether or not people like them.This show strips people of everything that is important, other than their body. They are measured on what they look like and little .As a result, lots of people have questioned the damage caused to the mental health of the contestants.There have been more than , complaints to Ofcom about this series already.But there are good things about Love Island.While it’s not exactly the kind of equality that women have been fighting for over the past  years, there’s no denying that female members in the house are as free as the men to proposition members of the opposite sex.In my day, all we had was: “My mate fancies you.” But Maura said of one guy that he gave her “fanny flutters”.When my daughter Sophia was asked to go on the show, she thought it would be fun to be on a free holiday. You can see her point.But no mother wants to watch their child on Love Island. We all know there are plenty of things our kids do that we don’t know about — and that’s the way it should stay.But it’s not just that. One reason I enjoy being part of the Apprentice is because it celebrates young people for their skills, ambition and what they achieve.They know they aren’t being valued for their looks — they are being valued for so much more than that.That said, no one’s self- esteem should be based on how others value us.I’ve often thought that my biggest superpower is that I really don’t care what people think about me.When I’m on the beach I’m not bothered about which bits and pieces are jiggling.Why  Because there is so much more to me than what I look like in a bikini.Or, rather, as a footballer’s we once said to me: “All I’ve got is my looks — at least you’ve got your personality.”I know it was a back-handed compliment. But you know what, I’m fine with that.LOTTIE Moss said on social media that she feels “uncomfortable” with her weight at the moment – as she posted a picture of herself in a dress on a night out.My first thought was she’s going to look back at those photos when she is in her fties and wonder how she could have felt uncomfortable when she looked like this.My second was she can’t worry that much because the dress she’s wearing is almost completely see-through.BOSSES of the Isle of Wight Festival have been criticised by two mental-health charities for banning Jess Glynne for le after the singer cancelled her show at the last minute, owing to anxiety.Anxiety is a debilitating condition which blights the lives of many people.I’m sorry to hear that Jess is one of those people.But when she knows she suffers from this condition, her choice to stay out partying with the Spice Girls until am on the day she was due to perform seems, well, questionable.Having been out drinking all night before work is enough to make even the most level-headed person anxious.To then go on social media advertising that fact, before effectively phoning in sick to work, is also a tad foolish.By doing that, Glynne gave the impression she chose partying over a commitment – and that is not a good look.If we have one job to do as parents, it is to teach our kids the importance of doing the things that need to be done, when they need to be done, whether you like it or not.When I see a young person doing what they said they would do, despite challenges, I know they’ve got backbone.It’s called resilience, grit, determination, and it’s about being irrepressible. Those are some of the most admirable traits a person can have.Anxiety is awful but it’s certainly not helped by partying until the early hours of a work day.THIS week there has been good and bad news for Boris Johnson. The good news is that it looks ashe is going to be our next Prime Minister.The bad news is not that early-hours row with his partner – it’s his new haircut.He used to have “The Trump”, a sort of comb-forward that hid his balding. But his barber has cut it off and, instead of the long-haired blond bombshell look, he’s now a blond basin with thinning top.Boris, please take it from me, when you go into a hairdresser’s the first thing you do is check out the hairstyle of the person holding the scissors.Anyway, I guess it grows back – and soon will be the haystack it’s always been. Now all Boris needs is a new suit.OOPS! My heart goes out to the mum of the rampaging toddler at a Swiss art show who knocked over a sculpture of a fly worth £,.My main question, though, is how a plastic sculpture of a fly could be worth so much money Someone, somewhere, is having a laugh. Right I WAS trying to work out what was unusual about the recent photo of actor Rob Lowe on the red carpet.I realised it’s this. He is a handsome, successful star who is still with his we – Sheryl Berkoff – after  years without trading her in for a younger model.And they look happy.A rare sight in Hollywood, so good luck to both of them.TO be fair, Sofia Richie pretty much pulled it off when she sported the latest bicycle shorts onesie – the trend you prayed would never happen.But all I can say is, I’m glad I don’t follow fashion.WHAT’S in a word  You might think nothing much. And it’s a small thing in a way, but Sainsbury’s needs to be called out for assuming on its hair-removal product that all doctors are male.Its instructions say: “Consult your usual doctor and show him the packaging.”No doubt lots of people will respond by saying that us women are far too easily offended.But it is assumptions such as this behind the fact that, for every £ a man makes, a woman only makes p.We have to stamp out this unconscious bias by calling it out every time we see it.AMAZING that it’s  years since Friends hit our TVs.But judging by pictures of its stars Jenner Aniston, , and Courteney Cox, , on vacation in their bikinis, they still look fantastic.Even more amazing is that they are genuine friends.It just goes to show thatyou eat well, work out and look after yourself, you don’t have to be fat and flabby at .*Note to self – eat better and go to the gym. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum groomed pimped out teen

He was a great manipulator but I never saw that at the time.“I’m thankful he’s been jailed and the world can see him as the monster he truly is.”Lisas nightmare began in  when she met Gorringe in a supermarket while shopping with her mum.As a friendship between the three blossomed, Lisa and her mum would go for dinner at his home and he offered to tutor her once a week in what the court heard was the systematic corruption of a child.We really thought we could trust him but I realise that this was the start of his trap, Lisa said.By December , Gorringes behaviour turned sinister and he touched the teen in a park one night leaving Lisa frozen in fear.He then began abusing Lisa a couple of times a week and bought her a phone so they could message in private.Then, in January , Gorringe raped Lisa at his home.She says: “The pain was unbearable. I knew he couldn’t get away with what he’d done to me.Gorringe was convicted of a total of  sex offences, including three counts of rape against Lisa and two against a teen boy - and one count of causing child prostitution.He was jailed for  years, with an eight-year licence extension. It means that he can be recalled to prison on his release up to the age of . Gaynor was jailed for six years for rape.Sentencing, Recorder Stephen Lennard described Gorringe as a dangerous offender.He said: You are a predatory and manipulative sexual deviant who stopped at nothing to obtain what you wanted.Lisa is now trying to move on with her le and hopes by speaking out, she can inspire other victims to do the same.She said: “It was a relief. title: beecham house self loathing british empire
story: Results were mixed.About a decade ago, though, television decided it was an evil almost beyond compare and we had to be apologetic about the British Empire, for all eternity, even during ITV’s Sunday night pm to pm slot.Latest result of this self-loathing is Beecham House, a lavish and expensive, not to mention dreadful, new ITV drama which is supposedly set in  Delhi but can be far more accurately carbon dated to the early st century period between March , when Poldark took his top off, to .pm on Christmas Day, .That was when the last ever episode of Downton Abbey finished, ITV execs panicked and suddenly thought: “Oh s***. We need another show with a big house and a strong, silent, topless gardener who gallops around searching for love, fulfilment and all that toss.”So we’ve now got this six-part series fronted by Tom Bateman, who actually made a promising start to playing soldier-turned-trader John Beecham.He got shot.I’d have run the closing titles right there and then and promised viewers: “ITV willin about , when it’s got some new ideas.”According to the caption, however, “three years later” John Beecham was back and he’d brought his extended family with him to fill the big house.They include: His dear old racist mum, played by Mrs Patmore off Downton, a motherless baby, wayward brother Daniel, some pot-stirring French git called General Castillion and two underwhelming bits of female love interest, who won’t get any bloke switching over from Love Island in a hurry. Also present is Citizen Khan himself, Adil Ray, who’s moved in next door wearing a glued-on beard that last saw serious action in Carry On Up The Khyber.So I hope no one was expecting a laugh, or a plot. Because Beecham House hasn’t really got one, apart from the baby issue and Beecham’s grovelling desire to be granted a trading licence, which both generate lots of sarky backchat from the locals, but not much .It all stands or falls then, almost entirely, on the leading character.And, oh boy, does this one ever fall.As absolutely everyone’s noticed, for the want of charisma they’ve had to dress the poor bloke up as Indiana Jones, which can’t be a lot of fun in that climate.Even with the overcoat, cowboy hat and women throwing themselves at him, John’s brother still thinks he’s “the dullest man in Delhi”.The thing that really weighs him down, though, is Empire guilt. The righteous berk can hardly look at an Indian without apologising.“Your Imperial Highness, I implore you judge me by my actions not my flag.”“I am not like my countrymen.” “Their hypocrisy sickens me.” “The East India company’s policy of expansion is shameful.” “I love your country and believe India should be ruled by Indians.”  He’s so woke he could be reading last night’s Channel  News.An approach that’s unlikely to win the show many friends, I’d have thought, or stop the more right-on viewers accusing him of having “big white saviour syndrome”.Ultimately, though, I have absolutely no real idea whether John Beecham will strike a chord with the viewers, because, like most shows broadcast in the Sunday night pm to pm slot, I am not part of the target female audience.All I’m meant to do is sit dumbly and join in the apologetic Empire chorus.I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I’m not sorry at all.TIPPING Point, Ben Shephard: “In Only Fools And Horses, who plays the character known as Del Boy ”Ben: “David Frost.”Fteen To One, Sandi Toksvig: “What is the two-word term for a flashing orange globe mounted on a striped pole, used at pedestrian crossings, named after a s minister of transport ”Kresha: “Traffic light.”And Love Island, Molly-Mae: “What is the capital of France ”PSYCHOPATH With Piers Morganrequires expectations to be managed, because it’s barely a minute old when Porky-Talkie reveals: “The prison considers Paris Bennett so dangerous they insist I interview him behind toughened glass.”Andthat’s not health-and-safety gone mad, I dunno what is, frankly.RE: Love Island. If Joe and Lucie were “Jucie” and Jordan and Anna “Jordanna”, did that make Elma and Scottish Anton “Elma Fud” NEVER a good sign when you can tell a show’s going to be a disaster just from the furniture.But that was the case with last Tuesday’s big political bun fight, on BBC, which looked more like a dating show or fire sale at Louis Walsh’s gaff than a debate to decide Our Next Prime Minister.It sounded like it as well, from the way host Emily Maitlis kicked off, barking: “Five men. One job.” A phrase I don’t think I’ve heard any presenter utter since Kerry Katona was fronting ElimiDate, back in .Long before it got to air, Maitlis and the BBC had also clearly decided Boris was the “Islamo- phobic” booby prize, because not one of the researchers saw any warning signs being given off by Abdullah, from Bristol, who’d deactivated his Twitter before appearing on the show. The prize guy, naturally, was meant to be Rory Stewart, who liberal political commentators all think would make a great Conservative Party leader, in the same way they probably think Iggy Pop would make a great lead singer of One Direction.Turned out, though, he’s a fidgeting little oddball who was political toast long before he sighed at Boris: “I’m sure, like me, you’ve been in Enniskillen sitting with sheep farmers.”So, by the end of the night, an attempted BBC stitch-up had accounted for: Rory Stewart, one anti-semite, from Bristol, some other bug-eyed Corbyn cultist demanding an early election and probably Emily Maitlis’ credibility as well.Boris, meanwhile, just ploughed on regardless.Well done, everyone.Celebrity Crystal Maze, Gemma Collins: “Just being honest, it’s an honour for you to have me.”And The Last Leg, Alex Brooker: “The problem with me swimming The Channel is I can’t swim.”Problem how ON Thursday’s Shopping With Keith Lemon, former market trader Rob Beckett claimed: “I used to sell compost and you can’t up-sell a bag of s***, can you ”Yet it never stopped him trying on All Together Now.IT’S nearly six months since that great foghorning orca, Gemma Collins, last made an exhibition of herself on television.So I suppose we were overdue Friday’s appearance on Celebrity Crystal Maze, where she rumbled round the course, like Indiana Jones’ concrete ball, alongside Carol Vorderman, Ellie Taylor, Rick Edwards and her on off boyfriend Arg.And how that pair avoided wedging themselves inside one of the show’s duct shafts will remain for ever one of the Channel  show’s great mysteries.Gemma bellowed over everyone, insulted her co-stars, threw a hissy fit inside one virtual reality game – “Nah, sorry. Stop the game” – and told host Richard Ayoade: “You must be clever ’cos I’ve got the mind of a genius and you’ve made me laugh.” She also attempted to create some sort of mystique around “The GC” tag, claiming it was nothing to do with her initials and inviting alternative suggestions from Carol, who remained diplomatically silent, evenI’d swear you could see in the thought bubble above her head  . . . “Gigantic consonant vowel consonant consonant.”THE Real Chernobyl proving the perfect accompaniment to Sky Atlantic’s show of the year.Susanna Reid’s digestive tract going into deep spasm when Geoffrey Boycott asked her out for lunch, on another unmissable Good Morning Britain.Top Gear’s Chris Harris attempting to drink a glass of water while being electric-shocked by Freddie Flintoff and Paddy McGuinness.And Alien Fun Capsule host Harry Hill responding to Stephanie Beacham name-dropping former Dynasty husband Charlton Heston: “Yeah, Charlton Heston. He was slumming it a bit after Ben Hur, wasn’t he ”ITV has just one brilliant comedy show. Harry Hill’s Alien Fun Capsule, co-written by Paul Hawksbee and Dan Maier.Slightly to my surprise, I’ve learned it also has a Head of Comedy called Saskia Schuster, who’s just told something called the Diverse Festival – and what a laugh riot that sounds – she will no longer commission shows written only by men.In the great sweep of ITV history, the possibility exists, of course, that someone has made a more stupid, pointless, self-defeating, virtue-clogged, brain-fart of a commitment than this one.It’s just that I can’t think of it at the moment.LAURA Bassett: “She had her arms by her side behind her body.”Casey Stoney: “Cameroon have got that no-lose attitude, eventhey lose.”Jordan Nobbs: “If England keep believing, the second half will come.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: travellers cant play the racism card
story: Last week cries of “Racist! Resign!” were directed at the homelessness minister Heather Wheeler.In an email written before she took up the role, Wheeler described rough sleepers in her constituency as “the traditional type, old tinkers”.The words were leaked and, lo, the outrage flowed hot and predictable. The Big Issue Foundation’s chief executive raged that such language, “has no place in this day and age” and so Wheeler should stand down.A travellers’ charity called her words “racist”, adding that “Irish traveller children should not have to grow up in a society where government ministers show such contempt for their culture”.Yes, Wheeler’s language was wince-worthy, but the leap to “racism” highlights the way race is used as a shield to protect the lestyles of some gypsy, Roma and traveller people from legitimate criticism.Recognised in the Equality Act of  as ethnic minorities, a force field of cultural sensitivity surrounds them. Any discussion of their culture can be labelled racist.Recent reports have found that travellers have it worse than the rest of us: Higher infant and maternal mortality rates higher prevalence of depression higher rates of chronic illness.They are likely to die more than a decade earlier than non-travellers.The educational outcomes for their children are terrible: The lowest attainment of all ethnic groups throughout their school years.They are far more likely to be excluded, and while  per cent of white British children stay in education past , only  per cent of Irish traveller children do.Officialdom’s response to these findings has been to blame officialdom or racial discrimination.The chairwoman of the Commons Women and Equalities Committee, Maria Miller, thinks travellers have been “comprehensively failed by policymakers and public services for far too long”.Always, the blame is directed at “the system”.Always, there is the retreat into the safe language of “vulnerable” people and “marginalised communities”, because politicians are terried of asking dficult questions about why travellers are over-represented in prison, or why many of their children are failing at school.Such questions would only spark accusations of racism and discrimination.This is not to suggest that gypsies, Roma and travellers live free from prejudice.There is discrimination which is real and cruel: Allegations of holiday camp operators having traveller blacklists pubs refusing to serve traveller families children bullied in school.Yet whose interests do we servewe pretend that all of this is down to straightforward racism The usually sensible Trevor Phillips, former chairman of the Equality and Human Rights Commission, has said that for gypsies and travellers: “Great Britain is still like the Deep South for black people in the Fties.”His analogy fails because it suggests the prejudice suffered is all about ethnic heritage, unconnected to the lestyle pursued by many travellers. This is nonsense.Though politicians will not dare say it, many in this country have negative perceptions of these groups because of their experience of illegal encampments on their local playing field: The littering, disruption and what might politely be termed “antisocial behaviour”.They see a group of people refusing to live by the laws the rest of us abide by: Trespassing on land with the police seemingly powerless to stop them breaking locks with no one prepared to arrest them parking on private property and not being towed away.It’s not racism driving this anti-traveller sentiment.It is fury that one community seems to live apart from the rules that govern the rest of us.The authorities seem pitully weak when it comes to evicting these camps. Councils must assess the welfare needs of those on the site before they can get an eviction order.Public money is sprayed on legal fees before the caravans move to a dferent illegal site, where the whole thing starts again.The authorities’ methods might be motivated by a desire not to “marginalise” travellers further, but it isn’t working.We need an approach which, while reconciling travellers’ desire to live on the move, recognises the desire of the rest of us to see the rules of the land enforced fairly.Part of this approach must be to make the process of evicting illegal camps surer and swter.But it’s no use simply wielding this stick without a carrot.The complementary action must be a building programme to create more authorised traveller pitches.Critically, each could have contact points with the local authority, with education and health systems, to catch these families in the net of public services .With more information on who lives where, the authorities could keep better tabs on who is educating their children, who is paying council tax, and so on.This issue may not make the hustings in the Tory leadership campaign, but it matters to the kind of country we are.Sensitivity to dferent cultures is right, butobjectionable or illegal behaviour cannot be dealt with for fear it will look racist, we are in a very strange place indeed.Giving one group a politically correct free pass denied to others is not fair, it is discrimination.Conservatives always talk about the importance of everyone “playing by the same rules”.Here’s a chance for the next leader to show he means it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gone is bumbling boris now comes mr slick boris ditches the bluffing for smooth performance as girlfriend sprinkles her magic dust
story: But the snap of Boris Johnson arriving for tea at the Royal Horticultural Society in Surrey today tells a story of just how much the man who could be our next PM has been changed by his girlfriend, Carrie Symonds.He stands in a smart, uncrumpled suit with hardly a hair out of place. It is a sign of the increasingly professional PR operation which Symonds has brought to Boris’ campaign.One of the things which has always endeared Boris to the public has been his refusal to obey the normal rules of public le.Where other politicians go around spouting slogans and with outfits chosen by professional image-makers, Boris has always been happy to appear as his own dishevelled self.His hair is famously a mess and his clothes never quite fit.Where other MPs give the impression as having prepared every word before they speak, Boris has always spoken with flowery language, often throwing in a word or two of Latin.What’s more, he has always been attracted to television cameras like a moth to a lightbulb, never turning down an opportunity to promote himself.But with his letime ambition of being Prime Minister finally on the verge of being realised, it is suddenly a very dferent Boris that we are seeing. Enter: Mr Slick.He has become shy, rationing media appearances to the bare minimum he thinks he can get away with.When he does appear, he is smarter, less rambling and more inclined to speak in prep-prepared phrases.It isn’t hard to spot the new influence in his le.Although only  -  years younger than Boris himself - Carrie Symonds already has a career as PR chief for Conservative Central Office behind her. She now works for Bloomberg.But asher day job weren’t challenging enough, she has an even more important evening and weekend job: tidying up Boris. It is a job she has taken to with great relish.Perhaps stung by Jeremy Hunt’s accusation that he is a coward for avoiding TV debates, Boris had a full day of engagements today – including interviews with LBC and TalkRadio as well as a walkabout in Richmond, West London and tea at the Royal Horticultural Society in Wisley.Besides his tidier appearance – his short hair is now always tucked in - there is a big change in Boris’ body language.While the new Boris gestures with his hands just as enthusiastically as the old one, he has introduced a new gesture – clenched fists – to give the impression of determination.Unlike the old Boris, he managed to sit through a half-hour interview on LBC without once ruffling his hair.He is much more guarded with language. On LBC, host Nick Ferrari questioned him  times on the origin of the photograph of him and Carrie in the Sussex garden.Where the old Boris would have answered the question with humour, now he evaded it altogether, always beginning with the same phrase: “What people really want to know about…”It is a sign that he had been coached specically in how to reply to that question.Gone is the bluffing. Gone is the bumbling. He is no longer winging his way through his interviews – he is sticking to a very carefully-worded script.The closest he came today to courting controversy was to tell TalkRadio that Britain will leave the EU on October  “do or die”.It appeared to be a clear commitment to a No Deal exit on that datehis other plans fall through, something which he has previously avoided saying. The political world should take it seriously – because there are signs he now means everything he says.When talking about his time as Mayor of London, the old Boris would have stuttered and launched into talking about his achievements with great rhetorical flourish.The new Boris, by contrast, has slipped into a habit of other politicians – he ran off a list of statistics which he hoped would present his time at City Hall in good light.Gone is the self-deprecation that was such a trademark of the old Boris. Not once in his appearances over the past couple of days – which included a TV interview with BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg - has he made a joke at his own expense.While the old Boris would have avoided slogans, the new Boris twice used the words “infrastructure, education, technology” – which indicates it is a phrase dreamed up by his campaign team and which he has been instructed to repeat at every opportunity.On Nick Ferrari’s show he made a couple of apologies – one for “the offence I’ve caused” describing niqab-wearers as looking like letterboxes and bank robbers, and one for the government’s social care policies.Boris is no stranger to apology – it was has always been part of his self-deprecating character. But there was an uncharacteristic sincerity in his words.Towards the end of the TalkRadio studio, his careful PR act seemed to be unravelling a bit.He ruffled his hair twice, started rambling that he relaxed in his spare time by making buses from cardboard boxes and couldn’t remember the last sports match he watched other than an England cricket match at which he fell asleep and couldn’t remember who England’s opponents had been.It was a brief glimpse of the old Boris – one which we are unlikely to be seeing much of in futurehe succeeds in achieving his ambition of reaching Downing Street.

story: No yesterday confirmed that Mrs May will leave office on the afternoon of Wednesday July .That will be a full  hours after the winner of the Tory leadership contest is announced by Conservative bosses, on the morning of Tuesday July .The revelation came after Mrs May’s officials conferred with the two challengers for her job, Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt.As The Sun revealed yesterday, CCHQ also confirmed the ballot of the , Tory party members will close on the preceding Monday evening, with counting of the votes done overnight.The PM’s official spokesman said: “We would expect the transition to the new Prime Minister to take place on the Wednesday afternoon, after Prime Minister’s Questions”.That date means Mrs May will have served three years and  days as Premier, making her the rd longest of the  Prime Ministers that Britain has had.Tomorrow she will overtake ’s PM Neville Chamberlain, who served two years and  days.But Mrs May won’t now overhaul s leader James Callaghan, who had three years and  days in power.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast glastonbury sunshine met office heatwave
story: The Saharan scorcher has emergency services on alert with healthcare professionals working around the clock to ensure readiness for the blistering weather.A Met Office health advice page warned: Healthcare services will be working to ensure readiness and swt action to reduce harm from a potential heatwave.Heatwaves can be dangerous, especially for the very young or very old or those with chronic disease.Craig Snell, a Met Office forecaster, told The Sun Online: The heat at the end of this week can be traced back to North Africa, but that heat has seeped into Spain and France, which will see record-breaking temperatures.That will then seep into the UK as we go into Friday and Saturday.Dr Emer O’Connell, public health consultant at Public Health England, added: For some people, such as older people, those with underlying health conditions and those with young children, the summer heat can bring real health risks.That’s why we’re urging everyone to keep an eye on those you know who may be at risk this summer. If you’re able, askyour friends, family or neighbours need any support.Warm weather is on its way for the UK tomorrow as temperatures could reach C but some will experience a muggy start to their day.The critters have been found hiding in kettles, toilet bowls, and even cups of tea.Fed-up families have even been forced to eat their dinners covered with giant NETS.The problem is centralised in Avonmouth, Somerset, but peoplein nearby Shirehampton, Lawrence Weston and Hallen have also been affected.Avonmouth resident Liesl Oliver said is is impossible to live a normal le with the flies swarming around.She fumed: You try and cook  They are there. Try and relax on an evening, they are landing on you constantly. Try and sleep  They are there.If Im not working, my days off are cleaning, bleaching everything, dont know why I do this though because you could have the cleanest of houses and youre still affected by them.They make you feel dirty.Brits in Scotland, Northern Ireland and South East England are in for a sunny treat today.Mr Snell added: Starting today we are looking at much drier weather across the board. A few showers in the South West but overall dry.It will be a dry day across many parts of the isles.There will be muggy start in the morning but it will gradually begin to break through the clouds.In Scotland, Northern Ireland, and South East England there is plenty of sunshine to be had.However, along the North Sea coast the clouds will linger there and places like Norwich will see temperatures in the high teens.Pollen levels will be very high across the UK.UV levels will also be high, so take sensible precautionyou are out in the sun.Thursday will see the temperature go up a notch to C giving Glastonbury festival-goers some reprieve after some people arriving early were caught in the mud today.That trend will only continue into Friday.Mr Snell said: It will be a great start to Glastonbury, with a little breeze to the far South West.We are looking temperatures in the high s, I imagine down towards the South West temperature will go up to C or C.On Friday temperatures will continue to climb with another sunny day across the board.Temperatures will go up a notch in North Somerset and Wales as it could tip to C.It will be a hot day for Glastonbury.The hottest day of the week will be Saturday as the mercury will comfortably go above C in some places - but it wont reach the record temperature of C.Mr Snell said: The heat will move towards the East and by that stage London towards Lincolnshire will reach C or C.Some places may possibly reach C, but as of now we are safe from hitting the June record of .C.It will still certainly be the hottest spell of weather this year.Millions in the South, East and Central parts of England were battered by monsoon showers this morning with frequent lightning as well as hail and high winds.Localised flooding was reported across the South East as commuters set off to work.Rail operator Southern reported that all lines from Brighton through Haywards Heath were temporarily blocked due to the heavy rain and flooding on the tracks, and some passengers were delayed by more than an hour.Coastal areas were the worst hit by the downpour, but some mm-mm of rain in the capital caused minor flooding on some roads, according to Transport for London, and it was a wet morning commute for many.Met Office figures show that June this year has been wetter than usual.Tesco aisles flooded in Stirling, Scotland after the ceiling collapsed amid a battery of thunderstorms.Video footage shows flood water pouring through the roof as stock crashed to the floor and water gushed down the aisles of the supermarket.The streets of Stirling were filled with rushing water as on video shows two lads sliding and swimming on the high street.

title: mum 15 children boiled puppies
story: Martha Crouch, ,  from New Mexico, is alleged to have starved and beaten her children as well as killed their pets.According to court documents, she took the puppies and put them into a giant pot and boiled them, making all the kids watch.She has been charged with child abuse and extreme cruelty to animals while her husband Timothy, , has been charged with obstructing an investigation into title: glastonbury festival open gates tents booze
story: Determined revellers arrived in their thousands at Somersets Worthy Farm this morning as they precariously balanced their tents and booze on their backs - or wheelbarrows.Campers were greeted by cloudy but dry weather this morning, with sunshine and conditions of up to  degrees from mid-afternoon.Temperatures are set to stay in the s throughout the week - but punters were advised to bring their wellies after rain on Monday turned the site into a mudbath.The hottest day is forecast for Friday, when temps could climb to C.Punters forked out at least £ for a ticket to the five-day festival, with Stormzy, The Killers and The Cure headlining this year.Festival stalwart Norman Cook, aka Fatboy Slim, has played at Glastonbury since  and will be performing three DJ sets this year.Glastonbury is a town the size of Colchester, populated by a bunch of lunatics escaping from reality and escaping from convention, he said.

title: san francisco becomes first us city to ban all e cigarette sales
story: E-cig manufacturers, Juul labs whose headquarters are in the city say that the move will deprive adults of healthier smoking alternatives.The ban could see Juul having to move its headquarters from San Francisco.Lawmakers say that a  per cent increase in middle and high school studentsuse of tobacco products is down to e-cig use, illegal sale of vapes and vape products to minors and misinformation about the dangers of tobacco product use.In San Franscisco, recreational cannabis use is legal - as well as the use of cannabis products in electronic cigarettes and e-liquids.Laws state consumption of the class B drug is okay as long as youre over , purchasing the cannabis from a state licensed seller and consuming it in the appropriate places - that means on private property, mostly and not in any parks, bars, restaurants or beaches. According to Dr Stanton Glantz, who is a professor of medicine at the University of Calornia San Francisco Centre for Tobacco Control and Research, e-cigarettes are associated with heart attacks, strokes and lung disease.Glantz, a supporter of the ban admitted that in his opinion, electronic cigarettes shouldnt even be on the market.Young people have almost indiscriminate access to [e-cigarettes] he said, and claims that the use of them has completely reversed the progress weve made in youth smoking in the last few years.The doctor said that due to inaction on the matter from the American Food and Drug Administration , its unfortunately falling to states and localities to step into the breach.In a statement to the Associated Press, FDA spokesman Michael Felberbaum said the agency will continue to tackle the troubling epidemic of e-cigarette use among kids.This includes preventing youth access to, and appeal of, flavoured tobacco products like e-cigarettes and cigars, taking action against manufacturers and retailers who illegally market or sell these products to minors, and educating youth about the dangers of e-cigarettes and other tobacco products, he said.But electronic cigarette company Juul, whose headquarters are in the city, oppose the ban - having framed the use of electronic cigarettes as a healthier alternative to traditional smoking tobacco.Juul say they have taken steps to deter children from using their products, describing their online age verication process, which requires e-cig users to enter their date of birth, legal name and permanent address into an age verication form, which is then checked as more robust.They have also shut down their Facebook and Instagram accounts to deter youngsters.Speaking out against the ban, Juul spokesperson Ted Kwong said the prohibition of vapour products for all adults in San Francisco will not effectively address underage use and will leave cigarettes on shelves as the only choice for adult smokers, even though they kill , Calornians every year.The American Vaping Association, like Juul say that the ban deprives adult smokers of less hazardous alternatives, going after youth is a step that you can take before taking these out of the hands of adults, said association president Gregory Conley.The e-cig ban follows a ban on the sale of flavoured tobacco last year, and a tax on sugar sweetened drinks in .However, San Fransisco celebrates its marijuana culture with one journalist describing the city as a hub for world-class cannabis in the same way the city is a meeting place and a destination for top-flight food, wine, and technology.Opposers to the ban also site the effect it will have on small businesses, saying that it could force some shops - who rely on the sale of e-cigs - to close.We need to enforce the rules that we have in place already, said Carlos Solórzano, CEO of the Hispanic Chamber of Commerce of San Francisco.San Franciscos mayor, London Breed, has  days to sign off the legislation, but has indicated that she would. The law would begin to be enforced seven months from that date.

title: fertility doctor used own sperm
story: It is thought between  and  children were fathered by Dr Norman Barwin, now , or by strangers - all without their parents knowing.Barwin has faced allegations spanning  five decades from the s that he duped desperate couples into raising his biological children.The investigation was launched in , two years after Dr Barwin retired in Ottowa, Canada.The College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario, who revoked the twisted fertility docs licence, called his actions beyond reprehensible.Spokesman Dr Steven Bodley said it was unfortunate that the only action they had the power to invoke was to take away Barwins medical licence.He added: You betrayed [the trust of your patients] and by your actions deeply affected iniduals and their families and caused irreparable damage that will span generations.  According to documents released by the College of Physicians,  cases had been documented against Barwin in which he had either used his own or unknown sperm to impregnate his patients.One unnamed victim said she felt almost asshe had been raped.Barwin didnt appear at the hearing, but the lawyer who represented him pleaded no contest.He had already received a short suspension from the college in  for inseminating three patients with the wrong sperm.None of the allegations have been tested in civil court but a medical  heard from his victims.Rebecca Dixon, the daughter of a family suing the doctor - her biological dad - said her whole identity was called into question.She didnt learn the truth about her parentage until she was .The idea that Doctor Barwin was her biological father repulsed her, she said, adding: It made me feel contaminated.An unnamed mother, who was unknowingly inseminated with the doctors sperm, said: I felt violated - dirty - almost asI had been raped.A dad who had raised his children thinking they were biologically his described the heartbreak as a quadruple punch in the gut.He said: Imagine the slow torture of watching my children grow up looking less and less like me.Carolyn Silver, acting as prosecutor for the college, called Dr Barwins actions an inexcusable deception.[His] shocking actions will leave an indelible stain on the profession, she told the  at Tuesdays hearing.

title: ae fingernail wait channel 4
story: Aaliyah, , had part of her nail ripped off when her  acrylic was caught during a fight with a pupil at school.The schoolgirl, who can be seen with scratches on her face, was immediately taken to St Georges Hospital, appearing on Channel s  Hours in AE.She could be heard complaining: Can someone please come deal with my finger.Im going to pass out.Shes told by her mum Maria: Your finger looks a bit swollen actually, with the teen replying: I think it is swollen.The teen had got her nails done the day before the fight.After being taken into a room, she was told by a doctor they would have to take the nail off.But viewers were less than impressed that she went to a packed AE for her injury - instead of a GP or minor injury unit.One viewer wrote: Watching  Hours in AE and the man with the stomach pains and the girl with the nail problem should have been chased out of there. It isnt a drop in for lazy idiots who cant be bothered either consulting a pharmacist or a GP.No need to wonder why waiting times are long!Another added: Watching  Hours in AE whilst waiting for Drag SOS with Gemma and theres a woman in the hospital bcshe broke her acrylic nail and its taken a bit of her normal nail off. title: bbc emily maitlis embarrassing gaffe
story: After some viewers complained about her chairing of the controversial Tory leadership debate, bosses wrote online that “her style may not be to everyone’s taste”.But the offending comment was hastily deleted after it was spotted by The Sun.A BBC News spokesman said last night: “An earlier draft of this response was published in error. Emily’s a superb broadcaster.”Miss Maitlis hosted live show Our Next Prime Minister last week in which Boris Johnson and rivals talked over each other and were put on the spot by an anti-Semitic Imam and a former Labour candidate.Yesterday afternoon the BBC complaints website published its first response to complaints from some viewers who “felt that Emily Maitlis was a poor choice of chairperson and failed to control the debate”.The response said the show was not meant to be a typical debate show and insisted that Miss Maitlis had allowed all the candidates to put their views across.It then went on: “We appreciate that her style may not be to everyone’s taste, but we consider that she did a good job during this programme.”Within minutes of the comment being spotted by The Sun and raised with the BBC press office, however, it was deleted.The later version of the sentence simply stated: “We consider that she did a good job during this programme.”Miss Maitlis was not available for comment.The Newsnight host has been reported to BBC bosses for allegedly spreading anti-Brexit propaganda, ex-culture secretary John Whittingdale revealed.And she was also slammed after letting her sleeping pet pooch take up a train seat earlier this week.

title: fly infestation heatwave weather
story: The critters have been found hiding in kettles, toilet bowls, and even cups of tea.Fed-up families have even been forced to eat their dinners covered with giant NETS.A ,-mile wide block of hot air is engulfing all of Europe, bringing high temperatures and storms right across the continent - but it will finally provide hot sunshine later this week.The muggy conditions are perfect for flies to breed.The problem is centralised in Avonmouth, Somerset, but people in nearby Shirehampton, Lawrence Weston and Hallen have also been affected.Avonmouth resident Liesl Oliver said is is impossible to live a normal le with the flies swarming around.She fumed: You try and cook  They are there. Try and relax on an evening, they are landing on you constantly. Try and sleep  They are there.If Im not working, my days off are cleaning, bleaching everything, dont know why I do this though because you could have the cleanest of houses and youre still affected by them.They make you feel dirty.Heather Duncan blasted: Its horrendous.As residents we cannot have our doors or windows open for fear of being invaded by the flies. Mealtimes are worse, trying to cook and serve food.I have to keep the windows and doors shut in the warm weather to stop them coming in.I have to hang that ghastly fly paper in my house and its an unbearable living situation.Council officer Dylan Davies said: We are aware of a number of complaints of flies and have been investigating potential sources and monitoring fly numbers year on year across the city.There is unlikely to be one particular source but these will include a combination of domestic and commercial waste and facilities where these are processed together with the natural habitat and the flies ability to reproduce quickly in favourable conditions such as during warm and wet conditions.

title: dwp two child limit forcing
story: NewsDWP two-child limit forcing parents to cut fresh food - and consider abortionsA damning study claims parents have cut back on fresh food, pulled kids from swimming lessons and even considered abortion over the Universal Credit policyShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN NewsParents are cutting back on fresh food for their children, a study says "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailParents are cutting back on fresh food for their children thanks to the cruel two-child benefits limit, a damning study says today. Others have withdrawn children from swimming lessons and school trips or been unable to cover gas and electric bills, the report declares. Several women told researchers they even considered abortions to avoid being left without enough to live on. The apostwo-childapos limit stops parents claiming Tax Credits or Universal Credit for more than two children - a cut of up to £, per child -the kids are born after April . It cut benefits for , families in its first year. By   it will hit .million children, including siblings who do get benefits, according to new predictions by the IPPR think tank.  IPPR added a million children already in poverty will be pushed further below the poverty line due to the two-child limit by  . The online survey of  families hit by the policy, between February and June , was published by the Child Poverty Action Group charity and the Church of England. aposJanetapos, a mum-of-three pregnant with her fourth child, said: I did try and go for a termination and I just couldn’t do it. She added: We’re in turmoil now thinking how are we gonna cope. It’s a constant worry, you’re constantly writing stuff down and checking how much money you’ve got. A second mum, aposKatyapos, decided to keep her baby because she felt it wrong to have an abortion for financial reasons. She said: I know some people – I know it’s not nice – but they would not keep their baby then. I wouldn’t do that. I’d make things work. A third mum told the study she would not have had an abortion, but evenI was to look for one I couldn’t afford it because she lives in Northern Ireland.    % of families who replied to todayaposs survey said the two-child limit had affected their ability to pay for food. One mum-of-four whose husband works full-time, aposLisaapos, said: I would have liked to get them fruit.I can’t remember the last time I made a fresh dinner, it’s all stuff I’ve got in my freezer. Another anonymous parent said: I can’t afford the full rentI put gas and electric on. Food is a minimum. A third parent, aposPaulaapos, said: Both kids have stopped their swimming lessons, we can’t afford it.Amy has had to finish her football and Corey his basketball… she was at football six days a week and she misses it a lot. Names have been changed. Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd has already cancelled a planned extension of the policy to children born before April . But charity and church chiefs today called on her to go further and scrap it.  CPAG chief executive Alison Garnham said: We wouldnapost turn away a sick child from our hospitals or stop them going to school. And yet the two-child limit denies families the support they need from our social security system when they experience tough times, trapping kids in poverty. We need to help children thrive, by supporting parents to raise happy, healthy children, especially during the first years of a childaposs le, when foundations are laid for their future development. Itaposs right to support families when they need it most. Our government should lt the two-child limit and help all children to thrive. The Rt Rev Paul Butler, Bishop of Durham, added: We believe that children are a blessing, not a burden, and that a third or fourth child is no less precious than the first or second. The Governmentaposs two-child limit goes against this fundamental principle and is pushing many families and children into poverty. It is simply not right that some children get support and others donapost. The two-child limit must be lted as part of a concerted effort to reverse the rise in child poverty. A Government spokeswoman said: “This policy helps to ensure fairness by asking parents receiving benefits to face the same financial choices as those in work. Safeguards are in place and we’ve made changes this year to make the policy fairer. “Tackling poverty remains a priority - we’re spending £ billion a year on welfare and providing free school meals to more than a million children.We’re supporting families to improve their lives through employment and latest figures show there are , fewer children living in workless households since .”

title: jeremy corbyn attend armed forces
story: NewsWill Jeremy Corbyn attend Armed Forces Day   Labour leaders plans explainedThe Labour leader is expected not to attend the national event for a third year in a row. But neither is Theresa May, due to a diary clash. And he is set to be at a local event in his constituencyShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsLast years national Armed Forces Day event was held in Llandudno "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn will attempt to head off claims heaposs snubbing Armed Forces Day for the third year by attending a small event near his home. Critics accused the Labour leader of disrespecting the Army, Navy and RAF two years ago when he went to Glastonbury instead, and again last year for going on an NHS march. This time sources say he will attend a local event to mark the day on Saturday. Itaposs worth noting Theresa May is not attending the national event in Salisbury either because she will be at the G summit in Japan. So before you see people talking about it, what are Jeremy Corbynaposs plans and what is the event  Hereaposs an explanation.  Armed Forces Day began in  after then-Chancellor Gordon Brown launched a aposVeterans Dayapos to celebrate the armed forces. It was given its current title in  and is now held on the last Saturday of June every year. There are hundreds of local events across the country, and each year one town or city hosts a aposNational Eventapos. In  the city is Salisbury, which then-Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson chose partly due to the bravery, dedication and skill tackling a nerve agent attack by Russian agents. The national event will include a military parade on Saturday morning, fireworks and a Kaiser Chiefs gig in the evening, and a world record attempt for the largest human poppy on Sunday.  The Mirror understands Jeremy Corbyn is once again not planning to attend the national event in Salisbury this weekend.Instead Labour sources said he intends to attend one of more than  local armed forces events near his London home.Further details of the event were not immediately available but it is understood it is an Armed Forces Day local event in Islington. Labour are in talks over sending Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Grfith to the national event in his place. Why are people talking about this  Jeremy Corbyn was previously subject to newspaper headlines and criticism from Tories when he did not attend the national event.In  he instead went to Glastonbury to give a now-infamous speech rallying the crowd with Shelleyaposs poetry. In  Labour said he instead planned to attend a march to mark  years of the National Health Service. Is Theresa May attending this year either  No. Neither Theresa May nor Lib Dem leader Vince Cable are attending the national event this Saturday either.That is because Mrs May is instead attending the G summit in Japan. Downing Street have not yet confirmed who will go in her place. A Lib Dem source could not immediately confirm who will go in place of Sir Vince. So is it a apossnubapos  Tory MPs have previously argued - and will doubtless in future - that Mr Corbynaposs decision to attend alternative events for three years is a snub. But supporters will argue that neither the Tory nor the Lib Dem leaders are attending either. And it appears his team are being careful this time to ensure he does pay respects to troops where. Itaposs thought further announcements are in the offing over the coming days to commemorate Armed Forces Day evenhe is not at the national event in person. Theresa Mayaposs team meanwhile are careful to stress that her non-attendance is an unavoidable diary clash. No hosted a reception for reservists on Wednesday morning.

story: NewsJeremy Hunt loses his s*** with Jeremy Vine for pointing out how rich he isThe Tory leadership candidate really didnt enjoy when how wealthy he was came up on the BBCShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsMr Hunt pictured here in more relaxed times "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMultimillionaire Tory leadership hopeful Jeremy Hunt lost his rag on the radio today after someone mentioned his enormous personal wealth. title: voice mirror assisted dying survey
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Choosing how and when we die should be personal choiceDisrespecting the wishes of the terminally ill and pained who yearn death is challenged when human rights suggest that we should all be entitled to end our lives in our own waysShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCondeming those who wish to shuffle off this mortal coil on their own terms to die without dignity and in absolute agony is cruel beyond endurance. Legalising assisted dying will for ever be a controversial issue with valid arguments on both sides – but the polling of family doctors by the Royal College of GPs suggests a sea change in public attitudes. Disrespecting the wishes of the terminally ill and pained who yearn for death is challenged when human rights suggest we should all be entitled to end our lives in our own ways. Protecting the vulnerable so money-grabbing relatives don’t bump off loved ones is vital yet that necessity must never be an excuse to force folk to cling on and suffer. Widening the debate and listening to interested parties, including doctors, is heading only one way. Choosing how and when we die should be personal.    Slither off, Boris Twisting and turning like a snake evading the truth, slippery Boris Johnson emphasises with every slimy response that he’s unfit to be Prime Minister. The arrogant incompetent’s humiliating turn after rival Jeremy Hunt forced him to face a few questions was the defensive squirming of a weakling pretending to be strong. Exposure of Johnson’s vacuous Brexit con job and staged photos to cover up a police call to his home are the desperation of a charlatan.    Met Police chief Cressida Dick’s declaration that worried neighbours were right to call cops to the flat he shares with a distressed much younger lover is a warning Carrie Symonds won’t be the only person distressed should Johnson trick his way into Downing Street. You Nellies It was acceptable once but most people now agree that riding elephants is cruel. ITV drama Beecham House made a mistake and next time, chiefs should make a trunk call from India to check with animal conservationists that an episode isn’t harming the animals.
